AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: a hybrid Elm that has good resistance to Dutch elm disease
alternate, simple, 2-4” long and dark green
light to dark gray with uniform furrowed pattern

At one time the stately American elm was the dominant street tree that lined boulevards throughout the United States. Many will remember how elm trees graced streets throughout Winona for many years. The near perfect vase-like shape created a cathedral effect as trees on both sides of a street arched to the sky. Then the dreaded Dutch elm disease killed millions of trees. While the disease probably originated in Asia in the early 1900s, it got its name because it was first studied by Dutch scientists. Since Dutch elm disease arrived in the United States in the 1930s, the devastation has been costly. Communities suffered such huge losses of elm trees that both urban plantings and nursery production of the tree virtually stopped. Today, 19 cultivars of elm are highly resistant to Dutch elm disease. Cultivars such as ‘Regal,’ ‘Dynasty,’ ‘Accolade,’ ‘Homestead’ and ‘Valley Forge’ are available as a viable option to the American elm. These new disease resistant elms belong to four main groups: Chinese Elm, Asian Elm, European and European-Asian hybrids, and American Elm. WSU’s Homestead Elm is a complex hybrid originating from the European-Eurasian cultivars. Homestead Elm was developed by the United States National Arboretum and released to the public in 1984. The tree produces an upright oval form with arching branches. It is fast growing and tolerant of most soils. It grows straight and tall, requiring little pruning. The dark green foliage stays green late into fall, unlike the other elms. While the Homestead Elm has good resistance to Dutch elm disease, it is not without problems. The Homestead Elm can be infested by the Elm Leaf Beetle. This excellent street tree has performed well in communities across the U.S. for more than 25 years and has eliminated the death sentence of Dutch elm disease. WSU’s Homestead Elm was originally planted about 15 years ago on Huff Street near Lucas Hall. After a number of years at that site, excavation for a new bus stop required transplanting of the tree. The Homestead Elm handled the move well and now resides on the edge of a grassy knoll located just southeast of Baldwin Lounge in Kryzsko Commons.
